title: Understanding Fibroids
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Fibroids are benign (non-cancerous) growths that develop in the walls of the womb (uterus).

items: Made of muscle and fibrous tissue
Can be single or multiple
Can vary greatly in size
Common and often treatable

content.title: Key Facts
content.description: Fibroids are not cancer, and it is rare for a cancer of the uterus to be mistaken for a fibroid.

content.value: Many people with fibroids have no symptoms. Others may experience:

items: Heavy or painful periods
Anaemia caused by heavy bleeding
Pelvic pain or pressure
Pain or discomfort during sex
A feeling of abdominal fullness or a swollen tummy
Lower back pain
Frequent need to pass urine
Difficulty emptying the bladder
Constipation or bloating
Difficulty becoming pregnant in some cases
Increased risk of miscarriage in certain situations
Tiredness, dizziness, or weakness related to anaemia

content.value: It’s possible to have more than one type at the same time.

items.title: Submucosal Fibroids
items.description: Grow just beneath the lining of the womb and may bulge into the uterine cavity. They can sometimes grow on a stalk.

items.title: Intramural Fibroids
items.description: Grow within the muscle wall of the womb. These are the most common type.

items.title: Subserosal Fibroids
items.description: Grow on the outer wall of the womb and may press on nearby organs if large.

items.title: Pedunculated Fibroids
items.description: Fibroids that grow on a stalk. These can develop either inside the womb (submucosal) or on the outside surface (subserosal).

content.value: The exact cause of fibroids is not fully understood, but certain factors are linked to a higher chance of developing them:

items: A family history of fibroids
Being of African or Caribbean background
Overweight or obesity
Starting periods at a younger age
Hormonal influences (fibroids are sensitive to oestrogen and progesterone)
Fibroids can sometimes make it more difficult to become pregnant, depending on their size and location
Some types of fibroids may increase the risk of miscarriage
Fibroids may be linked to a higher chance of preterm birth in some pregnancies
Many people with fibroids have healthy pregnancies
Extra monitoring during pregnancy may be offered if needed

content.value: Fibroids can affect more than just your body:

items: Tiredness or anaemia can lower energy levels
Ongoing pain and heavy bleeding can affect mood and daily life
Abdominal swelling can impact confidence and body image

content.title: Support Available
content.description: It’s okay to ask for emotional support or counselling. Living with long-term symptoms can be challenging, and support is available.

content.value: Treatment depends on your symptoms, fibroid size and location, and future pregnancy plans.

items.title: Anti-inflammatory medicines (e.g., ibuprofen)
items.content: Help relieve pain but do not treat fibroids themselves.

items.title: Hormonal treatments
items.content: Options such as the combined pill, hormonal coil (IUS), or progestogen tablets can help regulate periods and reduce bleeding.

items.title: GnRH Analogues
items.content: May temporarily shrink fibroids and are sometimes used before surgery or for short-term symptom control.

items.title: Myomectomy
items.content: Removes fibroids while preserving the womb. May be suitable if future pregnancy is desired.

items.title: Hysterectomy
items.content: Removal of the womb. Considered when symptoms are severe and other treatments have not helped. This is a permanent solution for fibroid-related bleeding but is major surgery.

items.title: Transcervical Resection of Fibroids (TCRF)
items.content: Removes submucosal fibroids through the cervix using a hysteroscope.

items.title: Uterine Artery Embolisation (UAE)
items.content: A radiology procedure that blocks blood supply to fibroids, causing them to shrink.

content.title: Key Point
content.description: Treatment choice depends on symptoms, fibroid type, and fertility goals. Your healthcare team will discuss the benefits and risks of each option.

items: Track your periods, bleeding, and pain to help monitor symptoms
If you have anaemia, eating iron-rich foods (such as leafy greens, beans, and lean red meat) may help — but medical treatment or supplements may still be needed
Stay active, manage stress, and rest when your symptoms are worse
Speak to your doctor before starting iron supplements, as doses should be guided by blood tests

content.title: Support & Follow-Up
content.description:
Regular follow-up may be arranged to monitor your symptoms and fibroids

Your treatment plan can be reviewed and adjusted if your needs change

Support is available — you do not have to manage symptoms alone
